Yes I agree with everything you said! And I wish people (like the author of this article) focused on that, way more than ‚Äúshe‚Äôs putting other sex workers out of work‚Äù.
I‚Äôm a law student and I recently took a course where we dealt with the development of sex working laws (in CAN). It‚Äôs really a dumpster fire.

I think there‚Äôs a difference between her acts vs her attitude being what‚Äôs rubbing you the wrong way. Back to the example, it would be like that celebrity author acting like they were better writers than people who were doing it their whole lives. So yes, I totally agree!

I‚Äôm going to get downvoted to hell for this but I really do not understand this whole argument. 

Snark on caro for a million different things, but people do not have the moral obligation to not work in certain fields just because others are struggling to succeed in them. How is this privilege any different than a celebrity getting a tell-all book ghostwritten while other authors struggle to get by? Yet we don‚Äôt come for them. We don‚Äôt ask them to acknowledge the struggle of freelancers or to apologize about capitalizing on their brands. 

I think this has a lot more to do with how people feel about sex work, period. We see it as a field for desperate people without options, and roll our eyes at anyone who does it by choice. Equally, I think there‚Äôs a lot more shock in a WHITE, heterosexual, cisgendered person doing it by choice, and I could write pages about what there is to unpack there. 

Idk. Maybe this is an opportunity for anyone who buys this argument to check themselves and think about why they feel that way...

I feel like the best way to describe him is ‚Äòformidable‚Äô.

It drives me nuts that there was a plethora of creepy, pedophilic, misogynist, abusive men on this show yet the only thing people seem to take away from it is ‚ÄòThAT bItCH CaRoLe BaSKin‚Äô. 

If you spend ~ 5 minutes researching her rescue, you realize how misrepresented she was in the show. The cages they show are not the ones the cats stay in. She does not breed. The rescue hardly accepts visitors. The practice of unpaid volunteering at these rescues is extremely widespread. 

Anyways. Imo Carole was genuinely the victim here. Hot take, but I also do not believe she killed her husband. He fits the profile of a drug trafficker perfectly, and it‚Äôs highly likely he got killed doing a deal.  Every business this illiterate man touched just ‚Äúmagically made money‚Äù? Money he refused to put in  the bank and instead buried in his yard? And he regularly flew to costa rica for ‚Äòwomen‚Äô? Come on. Not to mention that they updated his power of attorney to include ‚Äòdisappearance‚Äô precisely because of the type of people he was working with down there. And ALSO not to mention, but this POS abandoned his wife and children for a girl he met half his age walking (cough, working) on the strip in the middle of the night. Not the strongest character there. 

 If Carole knew about any of it, she wouldn‚Äôt come forward because any asset that was funded by criminal activity would be seized. Pretty simple. 

Exotic animal trading screams money laundering, too, while we‚Äôre it. Fairly safe to assume that all the men we saw were involved in laundering with various gangs, ESPECIALLY that fucker who ‚Äòowned‚Äô the strip club and  wants us to believe he flipped on longtime partners because of a LEMUR PERMIT?? It‚Äôs insulting.
I think that where they‚Äôre from, those tattoos DEFINITELY connote racism. Lol
I assume it‚Äôs because she‚Äôs been answering the same questions in the media for 20 years...
Literally the equivalent of saying ‚Äúcats like catnip‚Äù. Such a reach lmao
I think he‚Äôs in the 1%, hells angels or something. Everything he‚Äôs involved in screams money laundering. And he ‚Äòowns‚Äô a strip club? Yeah...
It‚Äôs the equivalent of saying ‚Äúcats like catnip‚Äù lol. Come on

Can you read? Her smallest ‚Äòcage‚Äô is 1200 sq ft. What they showed on the doc is the feeding cage, and viewers like you just accepted it with 0 critical thinking. 

There is also a maximum of 25 visitors a day at her sanctuary. The clip they showed was a once yearly event where people lined up. 

Come on.

Oh, come on. 

(1) I would say that about sardine oil, right now. If someone said ‚Äúthey put cologne on my shoes so the tigers would kill me‚Äù I would say ‚Äúoh, no, you would need catnip or tuna oil for that‚Äù. She worked with cats, no doubt regularly forcing them to take medication, etc., that was likely covered in something like sardine oil. That comment means nothing. 

(2) The restraining order was unfounded and clearly a tactic that often arises in family law disputes. His own lawyer laughed at it because there was nothing in there that actually justified an order being handed down. Don wanted to divorce Carole. It‚Äôs common in nasty divorces where there‚Äôs a lot of money at stake to try to file orders, tell family members the spouse is crazy, etc etc. 

(3) Who knows. Maybe she needed milk for the cats. Maybe she was involved in whatever drug smuggling Don was involved in, and so was her brother. Both those scenarios are infinitely more likely than her and her brother murdering a grown man, dismembering him, feeding him to tigers, and somehow getting rid of the remaining body parts (tigers are messy eaters). 

It‚Äôs insane. This documentary has cult leaders, pedophiles, domestic abusers, racists, hitmen, drug traffickers, animal traffickers, animal abusers... and everyone is fixated on the one woman involved who was clearly shown in a biased light to fan outrage. Unbelievable.

Edit: and in terms of the ‚Äòin case of disappearance‚Äô clause, she explains that directly in her statement about the documentary. She knew Don was involved with gang members (or shady characters) in Costa Rica, and it was common for people to ‚Äògo missing‚Äô under those circumstances. Hence introducing that clause.

I think the reason people look down on SAHMs is, like you said, because women who work do everything you do PLUS an 8-hour work day. 

I don‚Äôt think being a SAHM is easy, and I agree that it is a job. However, it is easier than being a mom and working a job on top of it. That‚Äôs an objective fact.

The problem is when we make it a competition. Although it doesn‚Äôt mean you should feel lesser than, you should also never tell a working mom that your life is so difficult... just think about that for a second. Imagine having to juggle a full career along with what you already do. The women who do that are the superheroes. That‚Äôs just the truth. So, while your struggles are valid, it‚Äôs not right to act as if being a SAHM is somehow on par with that level of workload and stress and skill. 

I also think that there are a lot of negative associations with SAHMs in our culture: helicopter parents, leeches, women with no lives of their own, women who turn to drug abuse out of boredom, get financially taken advantage of, join MLMs, etc... most of that comes out of not having an identity other than being a mother. I think if you can find hobbies and that sort of thing to fill your time, you‚Äôll be fine. If not, it‚Äôs sad. 

The point of raising a child is to prepare them for adulthood. If you put yourself in a position where doing so will cause you to lose your sense of identity, there is clearly a wild conflict of interest.

I‚Äôm going to give you some tough love. 

To this day, I resent my mother for staying with my father. We have issues. I think less of her. I think she should have protected me and my sister, but chose not to, because it was the easier option for her. I‚Äôm in therapy to deal with this as an adult. I have accepted that me and her will never have a close relationship as a result of her choices. 

I don‚Äôt know your situation as well as you do, but I think you might be heading down the same road. Husband snaps at the kids? Doesn‚Äôt help around the house? Cheats on you? Your kids are going to realize. They will resent you for the environment they grew up in. 

Even if it‚Äôs hard, it‚Äôs better in the long run for your kids to have a strong, advocate of a mother who puts them first rather than one who maintained the status quo for ‚Äúthem‚Äù.

Harrassment has to be repetitive. Broadcast means to the general public. You don‚Äôt understand basic principles of liability. It‚Äôs ok. You‚Äôre not a lawyer. But please stop trying to argue your point. It‚Äôs wrong.

Oh jeez. (1) Assuming you‚Äôre in the US, this isn‚Äôt harrassment. (2) defamation must be somehow broadcast to have standing in court. (3) there is a higher bar than this for emptional and psychological damage, thankfully. (4) you would need to prove that the venue was negligent in verifying that he was guilty to get his money back - there might be success here, but honestly prob not, given that the camera wasn‚Äôt working, they reviewed what footage there was, and they aren‚Äôt trained police officers.

The US has a reputation of being litigious - probably because of misinformed people.

Karmacourt doesn‚Äôt count. He can‚Äôt argue any of that because (1) the two people in line who saw this go down will not reasonably have any foreseeable impact on his job, income, or relationships, (2) social standing with your family is not compensable lol ‚Äî and he made the choice to tell them, not the venue. 

There would MAYBE be something there if he had been dragged out by police, if the incident had been recorded and spread online, etc... but on the facts any suit here would be frivolous. Besides, this would come down to the venue, not the woman who falsely accused him, so no chance he cares enough to pursue it.
You can‚Äôt sue without damages. What are his damages?
He wouldn‚Äôt win my guy

That‚Äôs a risk of overinflation (‚Äòas big as possible‚Äô). to make it easy, go on google scholar and look up  ‚Äòhyaluronic acid collagen‚Äô. There are a bunch of studies that have found that fillers stimulate collagen production. 

Scientific terms can make things complicated. For anyone who just wants to do some casual research, this is a great article that‚Äôs a little more science-y than the Allure one you have copied (although again, Allure was dealing with the risk of OVERinflation, which is why they point out that this is not a textbook complication) :
https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/plumping-up-the-volume-wr/

ETA: not to say this was your intention, but there‚Äôs a lot of this ‚Äògotcha!‚Äô schadenfreude-esque rhetoric around things like fillers or any ‚Äòvanity‚Äô procedures that women do. We almost *want* women to suffer for caring about beauty. Often it‚Äôs due to an internalized misogyny that most (i would say all!) women, and definitely all men, tend to have. Anyways, just a reminder that we aren‚Äôt in competition ‚ù§Ô∏è and i‚Äôm sure anyone reading this is beautiful inside and out with or without filler!

Would love to see your sources on that! I‚Äôve read tons of studies that back up the fact that they do, so i‚Äôm curious...

ETA: lol! Downvotes for asking for sources :‚Äô) i know ‚Äúit‚Äôs a conspiracy to keep you coming back‚Äù sounds good, but that doesn‚Äôt make it true I‚Äôm afraid...
A myth! (According to my dr lol). Fillers actually help stimulate collagen production, which combats aging in the area and keeps it elastic (so it won‚Äôt stretch out pockets).

üòÇüòÇ i know. Honestly though i actually have a lot of sympathy. Imagine living under that system? ? Not sure what you‚Äôre talking about. But for the record, I‚Äôm none of those things...which I know for sure, since we have very affordable therapists. üòå

Do you not know how it works? I pay for it. WE pay for it as a society. It is reflective of our social values that money be put into a pot to ensure equitable access to healthcare.

I pay nearly 50% in taxes so that both myself and my neighbor can get help when we need it. I had access to one of the best universities in Canada for pennies because our tuition is also subsidized by that pot. In turn, I‚Äôm happy to give back. Ultimately, Canadians care about the WE, not the ME. That is your problem in America. And you don‚Äôt realize that individually you suffer the worst. 

I‚Äôm sorry for you and I hope it changes.

üòÇüòÇ only in America would people look down on getting regular checkups, free medication, free testing, and free follow ups with specialists. All which, by the way, constitute taking care of yourself.

Hey! It is honestly pretty great. I usually only use it in the mornings after the gym, so I can‚Äôt really give a full review, but i‚Äôll try. 

Pros: it cleans your face without you feeling like you‚Äôre ‚Äòsqueaky clean‚Äô. The foaming is really nice. It leaves my skin bright and smooth. I don‚Äôt ever break out after using it. 

Cons: unfortunately, I guess I would say oil control. BUT this is really a ymmv situation. I use a really intense acne treatment set at night, so I wake up without a drop of oil. During the day, it obviously accumulates. So, I don‚Äôt want to blame the cleanser- I think I just get a normal amount of oil throughout the day. If you‚Äôre looking for something to banish it (if that exists), it probably wouldn‚Äôt be this.
